user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName)
{
    int32                             status;
    OS_impl_module_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_module_table, *token);

    status = OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl(impl->dl_handle, SymbolAddress, SymbolName);

    return status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
extern OS_impl_module_internal_record_t OS_impl_module_table[OS_MAX_MODULES]
...
typedef struct
{
    /* cppcheck-suppress unusedStructMember */
    void *dl_handle;
} OS_impl_module_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef uintptr_t cpuaddr
...
int32 OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl(void *dl_handle, cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName)
{
    const char *dlError; /*  Pointer to error string   */
    void *      Function;
    int32       status;

    status = OS_ERROR;

    /*
     * call dlerror() to clear any prior error that might have occurred.
     */
    dlerror();
    Function = dlsym(dl_handle, SymbolName);
    dlError  = dlerror();

    /*
     * For the POSIX DL implementation, if the symbol does not exist
     * then dlerror() is supposed to return non-null.  This is intended
     * to differentiate between valid symbols which are actually 0/NULL
     * and invalid symbols that do not exist.
     *
     * Some implementations do _not_ implement this detail, and dlerror()
     * still returns NULL after looking up an invalid symbol name.
     *
     * In practice, this is expected to be used for looking up functions
     * and as such all valid symbols should be non-NULL, so NULL is considered
     * an error even if the C library doesn't consider this an error.
     */
    if (dlError != NULL)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error: %s: %s\n", SymbolName, dlError);
    }
    else if (Function == NULL)
    {
        /* technically not an error per POSIX, but in practice should not happen */
        OS_DEBUG("Error: %s: dlsym() returned NULL\n", SymbolName);
    }
    else
    {
        status = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    *SymbolAddress = (cpuaddr)Function;

    return status;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I reviewed the provided function OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl and all related code and macros in the additional code. The MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 targets use of the string handling functions from <string.h> (e.g. memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn). None of the following inspected fragments call any of those functions:

- OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl (calls OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl)
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro and OS_ObjectIndexFromToken (indexing and pointer arithmetic only)
- OS_impl_module_table declaration and OS_impl_module_internal_record_t (data definitions)
- OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl (uses dlerror, dlsym and OS_DEBUG; no <string.h> functions)
- Assignment of *SymbolAddress and return handling

The only uses of string-like data are passing SymbolName to dlsym and to OS_DEBUG (format output). These are not calls to functions from <string.h>, so they do not fall under Rule 21.17. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation for Rule 21.17 in the provided code.
